Post.title: Hexo with Git
Post._content:
Hexo  (Use [Git Shell])
---
    
    > hexo new [layout] <title>
	> hexo new "file title"
	
    > hexo clean
    
	(generate)
    > hexo generate
    
    :
    > hexo deploy
    
    > hexo server
	http://localhost:4000/:
    
    More info: [Hexo](https://hexo.io/zh-tw/docs/writing.html)
	
---
Git
---
    Git:
    > git add .
    
    Commit:
    > git commit -a -m "update"
    
    Source filesGit:
    > git push origin hexo
	
	* TravisCI  Hexo :
	http://larrynung.github.io/2016/08/11/Hexo-Auto-deploy-with-Travis-CI/
	(git pushclean->generate->deploy)
	TravisCI: https://travis-ci.org/
	
	Git:
    > git pull origin hexo
	
---

---   
	1> git clone [url] [folder]
	
    2> CD [folder]
	
	hexobranch
    3> git checkout hexo
	
    4.PCNode.js    
    https://nodejs.org/en/download/

    npm,node_modules
    5> npm install
	
    npmhexocommand line interface
    6> npm install hexo-cli -g
	
	
    ex.
    [url]= "https://github.com/cpingwang/cpingwang.github.io.git"
    [folder]= "D:\blog"
	
    Open a [Git Shell]
    1> git clone "https://github.com/cpingwang/cpingwang.github.io.git" "D:\blog"
    2> CD "D:\blog"
    3> git checkout hexo
	
---

: http://larrynung.github.io/2016/06/29/Hexo-Post-asset-folder/

---

Post.title: Linux Command
Post._content:
Linux 
---
    : 
    # uname -a
  
    :
    # cat /etc/issue

    CPU:
    # cat /proc/cpuinfo

    Memory:
    # free
    # cat /proc/meminfo

---
LinuxProxy
---
    
    # export http_proxy=http://username:password@"Proxy IP":port
    # export ftp_proxy=http://username:passord@"Proxy IP":port
    proxy serverhttp://"Proxy IP":port
    example: export http_proxy=http://ping.wang:password@proxy.xuenn.com:3128
  
    
    # vim ~/.bashrc   //export
    # source ~/.bashrc
  
    YUM
    # vim /etc/yum.conf
    : proxy=http://username:passord@"Proxy IP":port

---
pscpWindowsLinux
---

    (0)Download pscp.exe
    http://www.chiark.greenend.org.uk/~sgtatham/putty/download.html

    (1)cmdcdpscp.exe

    (2)WindowsLinux:
    pscp Local_Path_FileName LinuxAccount@Linux_IP:Linux_Path
    example: D:\Tools>pscp "D:\DB Install\Redis_install_testing\redis320_install.tar.gz" root@172.16.45.105:/tmp

    (3)LinuxWindows:
    example: pscp root@xxx.xxx.xxx.xxx:/home/uploads/123.txt c:\

Post.title: Oracle ASH and AWR
Post._content:
ASH: Active Session History --> in Memory
---
(1sample,)
	
	V$ACTIVE_SESSION_HISTORY
	  - Displays the active session history (ASH) sampled every second.
	V$METRIC
	  - Displays metric information.
	V$METRICNAME
	  - Displays the metrics associated with each metric group.
	V$METRIC_HISTORY
	  - Displays historical metrics.
	V$METRICGROUP
	  - Displays all metrics groups.
	
	Top SQL:
	SELECT SESSION_TYPE,TOP_LEVEL_SQL_ID,SQL_ID,SQL_PLAN_HASH_VALUE,WAIT_CLASS,COUNT(1) as SECONDS
    FROM V$ACTIVE_SESSION_HISTORY 
    WHERE SAMPLE_TIME >SYSDATE-1/24 
    GROUP BY SESSION_TYPE,TOP_LEVEL_SQL_ID,SQL_ID,SQL_PLAN_HASH_VALUE,WAIT_CLASS
    ORDER BY 6 DESC
	
	ASHSQL plan:
	SELECT * FROM TABLE(DBMS_XPLAN.DISPLAY_CURSOR('SQL_ID'))
	
	More info: https://oracle-base.com/articles/10g/active-session-history
---
AWR: Automatic Workload Repository --> in Disk
---
(1/10ASH sampleDisk)
    
	DBA_HIST_ACTIVE_SESS_HISTORY
	  - Displays the history contents of the active session history.
	DBA_HIST_BASELINE
      - Displays baseline information.
	DBA_HIST_DATABASE_INSTANCE
	  - Displays database environment information.
	DBA_HIST_SNAPSHOT
	  - Displays snapshot information.
	DBA_HIST_SQL_PLAN
	  - Displays SQL execution plans.
	DBA_HIST_WR_CONTROL
	  - Displays AWR settings.
	
	Top SQL:
	SELECT SESSION_TYPE,TOP_LEVEL_SQL_ID,SQL_ID,SQL_PLAN_HASH_VALUE,WAIT_CLASS,COUNT(1) as SECONDS
    FROM DBA_HIST_ACTIVE_SESS_HISTORY 
    WHERE SAMPLE_TIME >SYSDATE-1/24 
    GROUP BY SESSION_TYPE,TOP_LEVEL_SQL_ID,SQL_ID,SQL_PLAN_HASH_VALUE,WAIT_CLASS
    ORDER BY 6 DESC
	
	AWRSQL plan:
	SELECT * FROM TABLE(DBMS_XPLAN.DISPLAY_AWR('SQL_ID'))
	
	More info: https://oracle-base.com/articles/10g/automatic-workload-repository-10g
    
---
ADDM: Automatic Database Diagnostic Monitor
---
--> 
 
 
---

---
(1/10ASH sampleDisk)
    
	DBA_HIST_ACTIVE_SESS_HISTORY
	  - Displays the history contents of the active session history.
	DBA_HIST_BASELINE
      - Displays baseline information.
	DBA_HIST_DATABASE_INSTANCE

	DBA_HIST_SNAPSHOT

Post.content:
ASH: Active Session History > in Memory

(1sample,)

V$ACTIVE_SESSION_HISTORY
  - Displays the active session history (ASH) sampled every second.
V$METRIC
  - Displays metric information.
V$METRICNAME
  - Displays the metrics associated with each metric group.
V$METRIC_HISTORY
  - Displays historical metrics.
V$METRICGROUP
  - Displays all metrics groups.

Top SQL:
SELECT SESSION_TYPE,TOP_LEVEL_SQL_ID,SQL_ID,SQL_PLAN_HASH_VALUE,WAIT_CLASS,COUNT(1) as SECONDS
FROM V$ACTIVE_SESSION_HISTORY 
WHERE SAMPLE_TIME >SYSDATE-1/24 
GROUP BY SESSION_TYPE,TOP_LEVEL_SQL_ID,SQL_ID,SQL_PLAN_HASH_VALUE,WAIT_CLASS
ORDER BY 6 DESC

ASHSQL plan:
SELECT * FROM TABLE(DBMS_XPLAN.DISPLAY_CURSOR('SQL_ID'))

More info: https://oracle-base.com/articles/10g/active-session-history

AWR: Automatic Workload Repository > in Disk

(1/10ASH sampleDisk)

DBA_HIST_ACTIVE_SESS_HISTORY
  - Displays the history contents of the active session history.
DBA_HIST_BASELINE
  - Displays baseline information.
DBA_HIST_DATABASE_INSTANCE
  - Displays database environment information.
DBA_HIST_SNAPSHOT
  - Displays snapshot information.
DBA_HIST_SQL_PLAN
  - Displays SQL execution plans.
DBA_HIST_WR_CONTROL
  - Displays AWR settings.

Top SQL:
SELECT SESSION_TYPE,TOP_LEVEL_SQL_ID,SQL_ID,SQL_PLAN_HASH_VALUE,WAIT_CLASS,COUNT(1) as SECONDS
FROM DBA_HIST_ACTIVE_SESS_HISTORY 
WHERE SAMPLE_TIME >SYSDATE-1/24 
GROUP BY SESSION_TYPE,TOP_LEVEL_SQL_ID,SQL_ID,SQL_PLAN_HASH_VALUE,WAIT_CLASS
ORDER BY 6 DESC

AWRSQL plan:
SELECT * FROM TABLE(DBMS_XPLAN.DISPLAY_AWR('SQL_ID'))

More info: https://oracle-base.com/articles/10g/automatic-workload-repository-10g

ADDM: Automatic Database Diagnostic Monitor

>

Post.title: Oracle Command On Linux
Post._content:
rootDB,oracle:
---
    # su - oracle
	
---
:
---
	$ lsnrctl status
	
---
DB:
---
	: 
    1)$ lsnrctl stop
    
	sysdbasqlplus
	2)$ sqlplus '/ as sysdba'
    3)SQL> shutdown immediate (shutdown abort)
	
---	
DB:
---
    1):
	$ lsnrctl start
	
	sysdbasqlplus
    2)$ sqlplus '/ as sysdba'
    3)SQL> startup


---
Oracle Enterprise Manager (EM)
---
    dbconsole:
    $ emctl status dbconsole

    DB
	$ emctl start dbconsole
	https://192.168.56.101:1158/em

	EM:
	$ emctl start dbconsole

    EM:
	$ emctl stop dbconsole

    EM:
    $ emca -repos drop

	EM(config):
    $ emca -repos create
    (EM: $ emca -repos recreate)

    emconfig:
    $ emca -deconfig dbcontrol db

	emconfig(SID,1521):
    $ emca -config dbcontrol db

    'job_queue_processes' must be greater than or equal to 1.,DB job_queue_processes=10 
	$ emca -config dbcontrol db

	$ sqlplus '/ as sysdba'
    SQL> show parameter job
    SQL> alter system set job_queue_processes=10 scope=both;

    System altered.

    SQL> show parameter job	
	
---

---
title: Oracle Command On Linux
date: 2016-06-07 10:54:38
tags: DB
---

rootDB,oracle:
---
    # su - oracle
	
---
:
---
	$ lsnrctl status
	
---
DB:
---
	: 
    1)$ lsnrctl stop
    
	sysdbasqlplus
	2)$ sqlplus '/ as sysdba'
    3)SQL> shutdown immediate (shutdown abort)
	
---	
DB:
---
    1):
	$ lsnrctl start
	
	sysdbasqlplus
    2)$ sqlplus '/ as sysdba'
    3)SQL> startup


---
Oracle Enterprise Manager (EM)
---
    dbconsole:
    $ emctl status dbconsole

    DB
	$ emctl start dbconsole
	https://192.168.56.101:1158/em

	EM:
	$ emctl start dbconsole

    EM:
	$ emctl stop dbconsole

    EM:
    $ emca -repos drop

	EM(config):
    $ emca -repos create
    (EM: $ emca -repos recreate)

    emconfig:
    $ emca -deconfig dbcontrol db

	emconfig(SID,1521):
    $ emca -config dbcontrol db

    'job_queue_processes' must be greater than or equal to 1.,DB job_queue_processes=10 
	$ emca -config dbcontrol db

	$ sqlplus '/ as sysdba'
    SQL> show parameter job
    SQL> alter system set job_queue_processes=10 scope=both;

    System altered.

    SQL> show parameter job	
	
---
Post.content:
rootDB,oracle:

# su - oracle

:

$ lsnrctl status

DB:

: 
1)$ lsnrctl stop

sysdbasqlplus
2)$ sqlplus '/ as sysdba'
3)SQL> shutdown immediate (shutdown abort)

DB:

1):
$ lsnrctl start

sysdbasqlplus
2)$ sqlplus '/ as sysdba'
3)SQL> startup

Oracle Enterprise Manager (EM)

dbconsole:
$ emctl status dbconsole

DB
$ emctl start dbconsole
https://192.168.56.101:1158/em

EM:
$ emctl start dbconsole

EM:
$ emctl stop dbconsole

EM:
$ emca -repos drop

EM(config):
$ emca -repos create
(EM: $ emca -repos recreate)

emconfig:
$ emca -deconfig dbcontrol db

emconfig(SID,1521):
$ emca -config dbcontrol db

'job_queue_processes' must be greater than or equal to 1.,DB job_queue_processes=10 
$ emca -config dbcontrol db

$ sqlplus '/ as sysdba'
SQL> show parameter job
SQL> alter system set job_queue_processes=10 scope=both;

System altered.

SQL> show parameter job

rootDB,oracle:

# su - oracle

:

$ lsnrctl status

DB:

:

sysdbasqlplus
2)$ sqlplus '/ as sysdba'
3)SQL> shutdown immediate (shutdown abort)

DB:

1):

Post.title: OracleServerArchitecture
Post.raw:
---
title: OracleServerArchitecture
date: 2016-08-23 12:24:25
tags: DB
---
{% asset_img OracleServerArchitecture.png %}

Post.title: Redo-Undo-Commit
Post._content:
Redo
---
    Redo log files are the transaction logs for the database.
	Oracle maintains two types of redo log files: online and archived.
	They are used for recovery purposes.
Redo logDB

{% asset_img redolog.png %}

---
    Every Oracle database has at least two online redo log groups with at least a single member(redo log file) in each group.
	These online redo log groups are used in a circular fashion.
Oracle DB 2onlineredo logredo log groups(redo logmember)

{% asset_img RedoLogMembers.png %}

---

Undo
---
    Undo information is generated by the database as you make modifications to data to put it back the way it was before the modifications,
	in the event the transaction or statement you are executing fails for any reason or if you request it with a ROLLBACK statement.
UndoROLLBACK

---
    The database is logically restored to the way it was, any changes are logically undone,
	the database blocks themselves, may well be different after a rollback.
RollbackRollback
	
---

Commit
---
    A COMMIT is generally a very fast operation, regardless of the transaction size.
COMMIT

---
    If a COMMIT of one row takes X units of time, and the COMMIT of 1,000 rows takes the same X units of time.
COMMITcommitX

---
    By committing only when you have to(when the logical unit of work is complete),
    you will not only increase performance,	but also reduce contention for shared resources
	(log files, various internal latches...).
COMMIT()

---
    It is best to size our transactions based on business need,
	not based on misguided attempts to lessen resource usage on the database.
DB

---	
    There are two contributing factors to the expense of the COMMIT:
     Weve obviously increased the round-trips to and from the database. 
      If we commit every record, we are generating that much more traffic back and forth.
     Every time we commit, we must wait for our redo to be written to disk. This will result in a wait. 
      In this case, the wait is named log file sync.
COMMIT:
 Commit
 COMMITRedoLogDisklog file sync.

---
    When we committed after every INSERT, we waited almost every timeand if you wait a little bit of time but you wait often, then it all adds up.
COMMITINSERTCommit

---
    Before we even go to COMMIT in the database, weve already done the really hard work. 
    Weve already modified the data in the database, so weve already done 99.9 percent of the work. 
    Operations such as the following have already taken place:
     Undo blocks have been generated in the SGA.
     Modified data blocks have been generated in the SGA.
     Buffered redo for the preceding two items has been generated in the SGA.
     Depending on the size of the preceding three items, and the amount of time spent,some combination of the previous data may be flushed onto disk already.
     All locks have been acquired.
COMMITDB99.9%...
 UndoSGA
 SGA
 Buffered redoSGA
 Disk
 locks

---	
    When we COMMIT, all that is left to happen is the following:
     An SCN is generated for our transaction.
      (SCN is a simple timing mechanism Oracle uses to guarantee the ordering of transactions and to enable recovery from failure.
       It is also used to guarantee read-consistency and checkpointing in the database.
       Think of the SCN as a ticker; every time someone COMMITs, the SCN is incremented by one.)
     LGWR writes all of our remaining buffered redo log entries to disk and records the SCN in the online redo log files as well.
      This step is actually the COMMIT. If this step occurs, we have committed.
      Our transaction entry is removed from V$TRANSACTIONthis shows that we have committed.
     All locks recorded in V$LOCK held by our session are released,
      and everyone who was enqueued waiting on locks we held will be woken up and allowed to proceed with their work.
     Some of the blocks our transaction modified will be visited and cleaned out in a fast mode if they are still in the buffer cache.
      (Block cleanout refers to the lock-related information we store in the database block header.
       Basically, we are cleaning out our transaction information on the block, so the next person who visits the block wont have to.)
COMMIT:
 SCN(System Change Number)
 LGWRBuffered redoDiskonline redo logSCN
 lockslock
 

---
    : Thomas.Kyte - Expert Oracle Database Architecture

     An SCN is generated for our transaction.
      (SCN is a simple timing mechanism Oracle uses to guarantee the ordering of transactions and to enable recovery from failure.
       It is also used to guarantee read-consistency and checkpointing in the database.
       Think of the SCN as a ticker; every time someone COMMITs, the SCN is incremented by one.)
     LGWR writes all of our remaining buffered redo log entries to disk and records the SCN in the online redo log files as well.
      This step is actually the COMMIT. If this step occurs, we have committed.
      Our transaction entry is removed from V$TRANSACTIONthis shows that we have committed.
     All locks recorded in V$LOCK held by our session are released,
      and everyone who was enqueued waiting on locks we held will be woken up and allowed to proceed with their work.
     Some of the blocks our transaction modified will be visited and cleaned out in a fast mode if they are still in the buffer cache.
      (Block cleanout refers to the lock-related information we store in the database block header.
       Basically, we are cleaning out our transaction information on the block, so the next person who visits the block wont have to.)

---
    : Thomas.Kyte - Expert Oracle Database Architecture
Post.content:
Redo

Redo log files are the transaction logs for the database.
Oracle maintains two types of redo log files: online and archived.
They are used for recovery purposes.

Redo logDB

Every Oracle database has at least two online redo log groups with at least a single member(redo log file) in each group.
These online redo log groups are used in a circular fashion.

Oracle DB 2onlineredo logredo log groups(redo logmember)

Undo

Undo information is generated by the database as you make modifications to data to put it back the way it was before the modifications,
in the event the transaction or statement you are executing fails for any reason or if you request it with a ROLLBACK statement.

UndoROLLBACK

The database is logically restored to the way it was, any changes are logically undone,
the database blocks themselves, may well be different after a rollback.

RollbackRollback

Commit

A COMMIT is generally a very fast operation, regardless of the transaction size.

COMMIT

If a COMMIT of one row takes X units of time, and the COMMIT of 1,000 rows takes the same X units of time.

COMMITcommitX

By committing only when you have to(when the logical unit of work is complete),
you will not only increase performance,    but also reduce contention for shared resources
(log files, various internal latches...).

COMMIT()

It is best to size our transactions based on business need,
not based on misguided attempts to lessen resource usage on the database.

DB

There are two contributing factors to the expense of the COMMIT:
 Weve obviously increased the round-trips to and from the database. 
  If we commit every record, we are generating that much more traffic back and forth.
 Every time we commit, we must wait for our redo to be written to disk. This will result in a wait. 
  In this case, the wait is named log file sync.

COMMIT:
Commit
COMMITRedoLogDisklog file sync.

When we committed after every INSERT, we waited almost every timeand if you wait a little bit of time but you wait often, then it all adds up.

COMMITINSERTCommit

Before we even go to COMMIT in the database, weve already done the really hard work. 
Weve already modified the data in the database, so weve already done 99.9 percent of the work. 
Operations such as the following have already taken place:
 Undo blocks have been generated in the SGA.
 Modified data blocks have been generated in the SGA.
 Buffered redo for the preceding two items has been generated in the SGA.
 Depending on the size of the preceding three items, and the amount of time spent,some combination of the previous data may be flushed onto disk already.
 All locks have been acquired.

COMMITDB99.9%
UndoSGA
SGA
Buffered redoSGA
Disk
locks

When we COMMIT, all that is left to happen is the following:
 An SCN is generated for our transaction.
  (SCN is a simple timing mechanism Oracle uses to guarantee the ordering of transactions and to enable recovery from failure.
   It is also used to guarantee read-consistency and checkpointing in the database.
   Think of the SCN as a ticker; every time someone COMMITs, the SCN is incremented by one.)
 LGWR writes all of our remaining buffered redo log entries to disk and records the SCN in the online redo log files as well.
  This step is actually the COMMIT. If this step occurs, we have committed.
  Our transaction entry is removed from V$TRANSACTIONthis shows that we have committed.
 All locks recorded in V$LOCK held by our session are released,
  and everyone who was enqueued waiting on locks we held will be woken up and allowed to proceed with their work.
 Some of the blocks our transaction modified will be visited and cleaned out in a fast mode if they are still in the buffer cache.
  (Block cleanout refers to the lock-related information we store in the database block header.
   Basically, we are cleaning out our transaction information on the block, so the next person who visits the block wont have to.)

COMMIT:
SCN(System Change Number)
LGWRBuffered redoDiskonline redo logSCN
lockslock

: Thomas.Kyte - Expert Oracle Database Architecture

(log files, various internal latches...).

not based on misguided attempts to lessen resource usage on the database.

 An SCN is generated for our transaction.

   It is also used to guarantee read-consistency and checkpointing in the database.
   Think of the SCN as a ticker; every time someone COMMITs, the SCN is incremented by one.)
 LGWR writes all of our remaining buffered redo log entries to disk and records the SCN in the online redo log files as well.
  This step is actually the COMMIT. If this step occurs, we have committed.
  Our transaction entry is removed from V$TRANSACTIONthis shows that we have committed.
 All locks recorded in V$LOCK held by our session are released,
  and everyone who was enqueued waiting on locks we held will be woken up and allowed to proceed with their work.
 Some of the blocks our transaction modified will be visited and cleaned out in a fast mode if they are still in the buffer cache.
  (Block cleanout refers to the lock-related information we store in the database block header.
   Basically, we are cleaning out our transaction information on the block, so the next person who visits the block wont have to.)

COMMIT:
SCN(System Change Number)
LGWRBuffered redoDiskonline redo logSCN
lockslock

: Thomas.Kyte - Expert Oracle Database Architecture

Post.title: Oracle Useful SQLs
Post.content:
V$Session

[Kill session]
Login as DBA...
SELECT * from v$session where type='USER' and program='SQL Developer';
ALTER system kill session 'SID,SERIAL#' IMMEDIATE;

[Kill sessionscripts]
SELECT 'Alter system kill session ''' || SID || ','|| serial# ||''' IMMEDIATE;'  
FROM V$SESSION WHERE username='xxx';

[Locked object name]
SELECT a.sid, a.serial#,OBJECT_NAME
FROM V$SESSION a, v$locked_object b, dba_objects c 
where b.object_id = c.object_id 
and a.sid = b.session_id;

System

[shared_pool]performancebuffer cache  **production
Alter System flush shared_pool;

[dbms_output.put_line('');]
SET SERVEROUTPUT ON;

DECLARE 

SET SERVEROUTPUT ON;
DECLARE 
  V_BUCODE CHAR(5):='BU003';
  V_WAGERSN NUMBER:=99;
  V_STAKEAMOUNT NUMBER;
BEGIN
  SELECT STAKEAMOUNT INTO V_STAKEAMOUNT FROM WAGER 
   WHERE BUCODE= UPPER(V_BUCODE) AND WAGERSN=V_WAGERSN;
  dbms_output.put_line(V_STAKEAMOUNT);
END;
/

DEFINE 

DEFINE BUCODE='BU003';
DEFINE WAGERSN=2066498;

select * from WAGER where BUCODE= UPPER('&BUCODE') and WAGERSN=&WAGERSN;

DEFINE WAGERSN=2066499;
select * from WAGER where BUCODE= '&BUCODE' and WAGERSN=&WAGERSN;

UNDEFINE BUCODE;
UNDEFINE WAGERSN;
Post.more:
V$Session

[Kill session]
Login as DBA...
SELECT * from v$session where type='USER' and program='SQL Developer';
ALTER system kill session 'SID,SERIAL#' IMMEDIATE;

[Kill sessionscripts]
SELECT 'Alter system kill session ''' || SID || ','|| serial# ||''' IMMEDIATE;'  
FROM V$SESSION WHERE username='xxx';

[Locked object name]
SELECT a.sid, a.serial#,OBJECT_NAME
FROM V$SESSION a, v$locked_object b, dba_objects c 
where b.object_id = c.object_id 
and a.sid = b.session_id;

System

[shared_pool]performancebuffer cache  **production
Alter System flush shared_pool;

[dbms_output.put_line('');]
SET SERVEROUTPUT ON;

DECLARE 

SET SERVEROUTPUT ON;
DECLARE 
  V_BUCODE CHAR(5):='BU003';
  V_WAGERSN NUMBER:=99;
  V_STAKEAMOUNT NUMBER;
BEGIN
  SELECT STAKEAMOUNT INTO V_STAKEAMOUNT FROM WAGER 
   WHERE BUCODE= UPPER(V_BUCODE) AND WAGERSN=V_WAGERSN;
  dbms_output.put_line(V_STAKEAMOUNT);
END;
/

DEFINE 

DEFINE BUCODE='BU003';
DEFINE WAGERSN=2066498;

select * from WAGER where BUCODE= UPPER('&BUCODE') and WAGERSN=&WAGERSN;

DEFINE WAGERSN=2066499;
select * from WAGER where BUCODE= '&BUCODE' and WAGERSN=&WAGERSN;

UNDEFINE BUCODE;
UNDEFINE WAGERSN;

Post.title: Redis Command
Post._content:
Redis
---
	Redis:
	# ps -ef | grep redis
    # service <redis instance name> status
	ex. service redis_6379 status
	
	:
	# redis-cli -p <port> -a <password> info
	# redis-cli -p <port> -a <password> info Replication
  
    config:
    # vi more </path/config file name>
	ex. vi /redis/etc/redis_6379.conf
	
    log:
	# more </path/log file name>
	ex. more /redis/log/redis_6379.log

    Redis instance:
	# redis-cli -p <port> -a <password>
    > shutdown

    Redis instance:
    # service <redis instance name> start
    ex. service redis_6379 start
	
	redis-benchmark:
	# redis-benchmark -h <host> -p <port> -a <password> -q -n 100000 -d 512
	( # redis-benchmark -h )
	
	Redislatency:
	# redis-cli -p <port> --latency
    # redis-cli -p <port> --intrinsic-latency 100


---
Sentinel
---
    Config Sentinel:
    # cp /redis/src/redis-3.2.3/sentinel.conf /redis/etc
	# vi /redis/etc/sentinel.conf (:)
	
	port 26379
	sentinel monitor mymaster <ip> <port> 1
	sentinel auth-pass mymaster <password>
	sentinel down-after-milliseconds mymaster 30000
	#sentinel parallel-syncs mymaster 1
	sentinel failover-timeout mymaster 180000
	#sentinel notification-script mymaster <script-path>
	
	#Add this two lines in the last
    daemonize yes
    logfile /redis/log/sentinel.log
	
	protect-mode no (sentinel)
	
	: https://segmentfault.com/a/1190000002680804
	
	[sentinel.conf:]
	#redis-sentinel /redis/etc/sentinel.conf
	
	master/slavesentinel:
    sentinel: # redis-cli -p 26379
    : > sentinel failover mymaster
    (masterredis.confmasterauth <master-password>)
	
	:
	# redis-cli -p 26379 info

Post.content:
Redis

Redis:
# ps -ef | grep redis
# service <redis instance name> status
ex. service redis_6379 status

:
# redis-cli -p <port> -a <password> info
# redis-cli -p <port> -a <password> info Replication

config:
# vi more </path/config file name>
ex. vi /redis/etc/redis_6379.conf

log:
# more </path/log file name>
ex. more /redis/log/redis_6379.log

Redis instance:
# redis-cli -p <port> -a <password>
> shutdown

Redis instance:
# service <redis instance name> start
ex. service redis_6379 start

redis-benchmark:
# redis-benchmark -h <host> -p <port> -a <password> -q -n 100000 -d 512
( # redis-benchmark -h )

Redislatency:
# redis-cli -p <port> --latency
# redis-cli -p <port> --intrinsic-latency 100

Sentinel

Config Sentinel:
# cp /redis/src/redis-3.2.3/sentinel.conf /redis/etc
# vi /redis/etc/sentinel.conf (:)

port 26379
sentinel monitor mymaster <ip> <port> 1
sentinel auth-pass mymaster <password>
sentinel down-after-milliseconds mymaster 30000
#sentinel parallel-syncs mymaster 1
sentinel failover-timeout mymaster 180000
#sentinel notification-script mymaster <script-path>

#Add this two lines in the last
daemonize yes
logfile /redis/log/sentinel.log

protect-mode no (sentinel)

: https://segmentfault.com/a/1190000002680804

[sentinel.conf:]
#redis-sentinel /redis/etc/sentinel.conf

master/slavesentinel:
sentinel: # redis-cli -p 26379
: > sentinel failover mymaster
(masterredis.confmasterauth <master-password>)

:
# redis-cli -p 26379 info
Post.more:
Redis

Redis:
# ps -ef | grep redis
# service <redis instance name> status
ex. service redis_6379 status

:
# redis-cli -p <port> -a <password> info
# redis-cli -p <port> -a <password> info Replication

config:
# vi more </path/config file name>
ex. vi /redis/etc/redis_6379.conf

log:
# more </path/log file name>
ex. more /redis/log/redis_6379.log

Redis instance:
# redis-cli -p <port> -a <password>
> shutdown

Redis instance:
# service <redis instance name> start
ex. service redis_6379 start

redis-benchmark:
# redis-benchmark -h <host> -p <port> -a <password> -q -n 100000 -d 512
( # redis-benchmark -h )

Redislatency:
# redis-cli -p <port> --latency
# redis-cli -p <port> --intrinsic-latency 100

Sentinel

Config Sentinel:
# cp /redis/src/redis-3.2.3/sentinel.conf /redis/etc
# vi /redis/etc/sentinel.conf (:)

port 26379
sentinel monitor mymaster <ip> <port> 1
sentinel auth-pass mymaster <password>
sentinel down-after-milliseconds mymaster 30000
#sentinel parallel-syncs mymaster 1
sentinel failover-timeout mymaster 180000
#sentinel notification-script mymaster <script-path>

#Add this two lines in the last
daemonize yes
logfile /redis/log/sentinel.log

protect-mode no (sentinel)

: https://segmentfault.com/a/1190000002680804

[sentinel.conf:]
#redis-sentinel /redis/etc/sentinel.conf

master/slavesentinel:
sentinel: # redis-cli -p 26379
: > sentinel failover mymaster
(masterredis.confmasterauth <master-password>)

:
# redis-cli -p 26379 info

Post.title: Execution Plan and Performance Tunning
Post._content:
Execution Plan
---
    QueryQuery Optimizerquery
    (CBO)
    Optimizer(CPUI/O)
    CostExecution PlanQuery
---
Optimizer
---
    Optimizer
    
    ()
    
    Parameter sniffing
    1.OPTION (RECOMPILE)
    2.OPTION (OPTIMIZE FOR (@VARIABLE=VALUE))
    3.OPTION (OPTIMIZE FOR (@VARIABLE UNKNOWN))
    4.Use local variables
---
How to read Execution Plan:
---
    
    ?
    ?(Operation)
    ?
    
    1.Table Scan
        
    2.Index Scan
        Table Scan
    3.Index Seek
        
    4.Clustered Index ScanTable ScanIndex
       
       Table Scan
    5.Clustered Index Seek
---
Join
---
    Nested Loop Join () : 
    Merge Join () : 
    Hash Join () : 
---
SARG
---
    seek:=><betweenlike(ex:'allen%')
    Not Seek: Like '%A%'Like '%A' year(c1)=2016c1+15=115In

---
tunning
---
    set statistics io,time,profile on;

    1.(Scan count)/
    -  0
       WHERE Primary_Key_Column = <value>
    -  1
        WHERE Clustered_Index_Key_Column = <value>
    -  N / N

    2.(Logical reads)
    - pageKKBSQL Server
      Read/Writre1SQLI/OI/O
      

    3.(physical reads)
    
    4.(read-ahead reads)
    - +SQL Server0..

    5.LOB(lob logical reads) textntextimage  (varchar(max)nvarchar(max)varbinary(max)) 
    
    6.LOB(lob physical reads) textntextimage
